body: Having going back through the commits and testing against each ref, I've found that it's PR #49470 that has caused this

That is the intended behavior. It was mode to detect when the schema would not work in production. The model doesn't have a table, so either you remove action text from the application, or you install its migration and run them.
This was a brand new Rails 7.1.0 app, which action text wasn't installed or activated though

> This was a brand new Rails 7.1.0 app, which action text wasn't installed or activated though

https://github.com/deanpcmad/blogtest/blob/62f67c3c773f27886cef80843ecee078d6c71603/config/application.rb#L3

`rails/all` initializes all of the Rails frameworks

Edit: I do agree that it seems a bit odd that tests will fail after running `rails new` without running `:install` for certain frameworks, that does seem like a bad user experience

After setting the following in `config/application.rb`, tests now pass:

```ruby
require "active_record/railtie"
# require "active_storage/engine"
require "action_controller/railtie"
require "action_view/railtie"
require "action_mailer/railtie"
require "active_job/railtie"
require "action_cable/engine"
# require "action_mailbox/engine"
# require "action_text/engine"
require "rails/test_unit/railtie"
```

But you're right, it's not a good user experience. Especially for new users. I've wasted about 2 hours of work time trying to fix this as I thought it was an issue with CI :laughing:

Reopening as I don't think this is a good first run experience, but if it's the approach we are taking it should be in the getting started guide. Seems unlikely to me that every app will setup action text, active storage, and action mailbox before they attempt a CI run.

Edit: am I right in saying this issue does not exist in production, only in CI? As far as I know you can run `rails/all` in production even if you haven't created the action text tables, and it'll work fine as long as you don't access action text functionality.

issue.title: When running in CI, do not fail if Rails frameworks with tables have not been fully installed
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/49500

The Rails first run experience should not require installing Action Text/Active Storage/Action Mailbox so you can run tests in CI. You should only install these features if you actually use them. It also should not require changing the require of `rails/all`.

This config works in production when eager loaded, so we should support it in test too.

With this PR we keep the first run experience we had before `7.1.0` but you can still customise all these things if you want.

body: This is intended behavior. Again, if you don't want action text, remove it. If you want it, run the task. I'm ok with us running the task automatically, but I don't think we should avoid checking if those tables exists or not.
I was not supposed to close again, just comment that the solution for this problem is to run the install commands, or remove the frameworks you don't want.
Excellent, thanks for all you do, Rafael!

issue.title: Brand new Rails 7.1 repo with no tests pass locally but not on GitHub Action.
issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce

 1. Run "rails new oct10"
     * URL: https://github.com/jasnow/oct10 
 2. Copied .rvmrc from another repo to use 3.3.0-preview2 and Rails 7.1.
 3. Copied .github/workflows/rubyonrails.yml from another repo.
 4. Created "oct10" on GitHub and ran these commands:
    * git remote add origin git@github.com:jasnow/oct10.git
    * git branch -M main
    * git push -u origin main
 5. Ran "rake db:create:all db:migrate"
 6. Ran "rake" (no tests)
 7. Push code to GitHub and "test" action failed with this msg:
    * /home/runner/work/oct10/oct10/vendor/bundle/ruby/3.3.0+0/gems/activerecord-7.1.0/lib/active_record/connection_adapters/
       sqlite3_adapter.rb:458:in `table_structure': **Could not find  table 'action_text_rich_texts'** (ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid)

Will be glad to provide additional information as needed.

### Expected behavior

I expect the local and GitHub Action behavior to be the same.

**Not that Rails 7.1.0.rc2 did not have this problem.**

### Actual behavior

Local "rake" ran with no errors but GitHub Action "rake" failed.

### System configuration

Rails 7.1.0

Ruby 3.3.0-preview2

OS: Ubuntu
